newsitem.title: USA: U.S. ag attache shaves Taiwan corn import forecast.
newsitem.headline: U.S. ag attache shaves Taiwan corn import forecast.

text.p: A U.S. agricultural attache shaved his forecast for Taiwan's total corn imports to 5.02 million tonnes for 1997 from 6.50 million tonnes seen in a previous estimate, because of an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease among hogs there.

In a report dated March 27 that was released here Thursday, the attache said the new forecast was also down from 5.98 million tonnes of corn imported by Taiwan in 1996. Of that total, 5.80 million tonnes was supplied by the United States.
The attache estimated Taiwan hog numbers would fall by 1.5 million, but said the expected shortfall in hog feeds would be made up somewhat by increased poultry and fish production.
In separate report, the attache pegged Taiwan 1997 soybean imports at 2.2 million tonnes, down by 370,000 tonnes from the 1996 level.
Attache reports are not official USDA data.

Taiwan will have a shortage of soybean oil due to a decrease of domestic soybeans crushed, the attache said, saying there would be an increase in sunflower oil and canola oil imports in 1997 and 1998.
